Award.AbstractNarration:
1650574
Manousiouthakis, Vasilios I.

The emergence of shale formations as a source of oil and natural gas has prompted unprecedented commercial interest in utilizing the lighter compressible hydrocarbon gases (so-called natural gas liquids) as feedstocks for the production of chemicals. For remote shale formations, however, where the gaseous light-ends (predominantly methane) cannot be readily transported, this has led to gas flaring with associated loss of a high-hydrogen resource, and more significantly, a greater atmospheric burden of carbon dioxide with its greenhouse gas impact. Thus, technologies suitable for converting "stranded" methane directly to larger, liquid or compressible hydrocarbons are highly desired. Commercial chemical processes have traditionally been deployed using a scale-up process that takes advantage of "economies of unit scale". This requires large, high risk, capital investments. An alternative paradigm involves the deployment of modular chemical plants that can evolve from small to large scale through parallel module use that takes advantage of "economies of mass production". The proposed research focuses on the development of a systematic methodology for the automatic synthesis of globally optimal, modular, intensified, process flowsheets, that employ a variety of process units, including reactors, separators, pumps, compressors, turbines, valves, heat exchangers, and many others.

The proposed methodology will be based on the use of infinite dimensional programs with feasible regions defined by linear constraints, and objective functions which capture "economies of mass production". Their solution will be pursued through solution of finite dimensional programs of ever-increasing size, which always remain feasible and possess significant invention capabilities. The presented case study involves reactions producing acetic acid and formic acid from natural gas. For this reason, alternative methods suggesting the creation of subsystems including the steam methane reforming are presented along with novel ways of separating azeotropes. Successful conclusion of this high-risk research project will have a broad positive impact on process optimization methods, process intensification, modular manufacturing, chemical process manufacturing, power generation, and renewable energy resource development, and will result in the creation of transformative and revolutionary modular, intensified, process flowsheets, and in advances in the optimization of linearly constrained programs.

The award is co-funded by the ENG Office of Emerging Frontiers and Multidisciplinary Activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the NSF EAGER award titled “Optimal Modular Process Synthesis” the main objective of the project was the study of modular process optimal synthesis through a variety of methods. These methods include the application of energetic self-sufficiency, which can be defined as an open thermodynamic system operating in a steady-state manner that does not have energy inflow in the form of shaft work and heat, and the application of process intensification through optimization of process networks. These methodologies were applied to several case studies featuring the processing of natural gas, the production of hydrogen, and the analysis of reactive distillation networks.

The energetic self-sufficiency methodology was applied to two case studies involving natural gas. The first focused on hydrogen production from natural gas with the co-production of acetic acid and electricity. The project resulted in the development of a flowsheet that can co-produce acetic acid and hydrogen/power from natural gas, while generating no carbon dioxide emissions. This is accomplished through a reaction cluster; whose constitutive reactions represent late development stage or commercially available technologies. The concept of energetic self-sufficiency manifests itself through constraints on the systems’ oxygen feed, acetic acid production, and plant operating range. This work on acetic acid and hydrogen/power production has been published in the Journal of Natural Gas Science and Engineering[1]. Supplementing this research effort is a software for reaction clusters synthesis. Such reaction clusters can be generated using a rigorous lexicographic approach that carries out half-reaction generation prior to the incorporation of thermodynamic feasibility and other constraints into the synthesis process.  A half-reaction lexicon is created to identify intermediate full reactions, which in turn are assessed for thermodynamic feasibility, for possible incorporation into the reaction cluster. Thermodynamically feasible reaction clusters can then be identified, over a specified temperature range, as well as a selected species database.

The second energetic self-sufficiency case study resulted in the creation of a process that co-produces hydrogen and formic acid from natural gas, without any carbon dioxide emissions. Again, a reaction cluster, consisting of commercially available technologies, is employed. Energetic self-sufficiency was also imposed on the system determining the operating limits of the proposed process, which employs technologies including dry reforming, pressure-swing adsorption, combustion, and water-gas shift reactors. This work has also been published[2] and along with the acetic acid hydrogen/power production from natural gas both of these studies satisfy the objectives of the EAGER proposal. These projects focused on modular processes that imposed energetic self-sufficiency to flowsheets containing natural gas and co-producing valuable chemicals and electricity. Supplementing the concept of energetic self-sufficiency was the novel concept of “Sustainability Over Set” (SOS), which helps establish the well-posedness of the question “is a system sustainable?”. This concept is first presented in a publication[3], and can help determine whether the above synthesized processes are sustainable.

Aside from the above described energetic self-sufficiency methodology, a methodology for the systematic intensification of modular processes was proposed, which involved the solution of infinite dimensional optimization programs with linear feasible regions. This process intensification methodology was applied to reactive distillation, and hydrogen production through steam-methane reforming. For reactive distillation, a case study was carried out involving the metathesis of 2-pentene. This work has been published in Computers and Chemical Engineering[4]. For the production of hydrogen through natural gas, the concept of “energetically enhanced steam methane reforming” was explored, and a parametric study on the production of H2 utilizing hybrid energy sources was carried out. This work has been submitted for publication[5].

In summary, four research articles have been published, and one research article has been submitted for publication, summarizing the project’s key outcomes and disseminating its results to the public.

 


[1] Somiari, Ibubeleye, and Vasilios Manousiouthakis. "Coproduction of acetic acid and hydrogen/power from natural gas with zero carbon dioxide emissions." AIChE Journal (2017).

[2] Lopez, Jorge A. Pena, Ibubeleye Somiari, and Vasilios I. Manousiouthakis. "Hydrogen/formic acid production from natural gas with zero carbon dioxide emissions." Journal of Natural Gas Science and Engineering (2017).

[3] Manousiouthakis, Vasilios I., and Masih Jorat. "Sustainability over sets." Environmental Progress & Sustainable Energy (2017).

[4] da Cruz, Flavio Eduardo, and Vasilios I. Manousiouthakis. "Process intensification of reactive separator networks through the IDEAS conceptual framework." Computers & Chemical Engineering 105 (2017): 39-55.

[5] Pichardo, P., & Manousiouthakis, V. I. (2017). Parametric Studies on Natural Gas Based Hydrogen Production Utilizing Hybrid Energy Sources. Submitted to Smart and Sustainable Manufacturing Systems
